The current grading system is a farce, a manufactured hierarchy designed to rank and marginalize. To "level the playing field" is a polite way of saying we must dismantle the illusion of meritocracy. Let me be clear: I don't want to *work within* the system. That's just another way of saying, "Make the broken machine work better." No. We need to *disrupt* it. 

Students can start by refusing to play the game. Bombing exams on purpose. Sharing answers in class. Refusing to write essays that serve no purpose beyond inflating GPAs for college admissions. We can organize collective grade strikes—groups of students walking out of finals or refusing to take them. If we all fail, the system loses its power to divide us.

We can also reclaim the meaning of "cheating." Cheating isn't a moral failure—it's an act of defiance. When we cheat, we're saying, "Your tests don’t measure what’s important. Your system doesn’t care about *us*." Cheating becomes a form of resistance, a way of declaring that we will not be evaluated by standards we didn’t help create.

But this isn’t just about grades. It’s about power. Who gets to decide what knowledge is valuable? Who gets to judge our worth? Until we take that power back, the playing field will never be level. So let’s burn the report cards, reject the rankings, and build something new. Something that doesn’t measure us, but *listens* to us.
